Kierkegaard’s Critique of Political Rationalism

Robert Wyllie

Abstract

This chapter analyzes Søren Kierkegaard’s attempt in Two Ages to refute the apparent rationality of political discourse in public media during the 1840s. Kierkegaard identifies a separation between political speech and political action, because in the present age citizens lack the passion to match their words with deeds. Instead, Kierkegaard tries to unmask ulterior motives like envy and status competition that motivate apparently rational political discourse. The chapter aims to clarify the sense in which Kierkegaard is a critic of political rationalism, the limits of his critique, and its continuing relevance today.
